declarations.comments:
`GCodec` is defined as a `Profunctor` so that `lmap` can be used to target
specific fields when defining a codec for a product type. This operator
is a convenience for that:

``` purescript
tupleCodec =
  Tuple
    <$> fst ~ fstCodec
    <*> snd ~ sndCodec
```
Codec type for `Json` values.
declarations.title: JsonCodec

declarations.comments: Error type for failures while decoding.
declarations.title: JsonDecodeError

declarations.comments: Prints a `JsonDecodeError` as a somewhat readable error message.
declarations.title: printJsonDecodeError

declarations.comments: The "identity codec" for `Json` values.
declarations.title: json

declarations.comments: A codec for `null` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments: A codec for `Boolean` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: boolean

declarations.comments: A codec for `Number` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: number

declarations.comments: A codec for `Int` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: int

declarations.comments: A codec for `String` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: string

declarations.comments: A codec for `Char` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: char

declarations.comments: A codec for `Void` values.
declarations.title: void

declarations.comments:
A codec for a `JArray` values in `Json`. This does not decode the values
of the array, for that use `array` for a general array decoder, or
`indexedArray` with `index` to decode fixed length array encodings.
declarations.title: jarray

declarations.comments: A codec for `JObject` values in `Json`.
declarations.title: jobject

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Array` values.
```purescript
decodeIntArray ∷ Json → Either JsonDecodeError (Array Int)
decodeIntArray = decode (array int)
```
declarations.title: array

declarations.comments: Codec type for specifically indexed `JArray` elements.
declarations.title: JIndexedCodec

declarations.comments:
A codec for types that are encoded as an array with a specific layout.

For example, given that we'd like to encode a Person as a 2-element array,
like so `[ "Karl", 25 ]`, we could write the following codec:

```purescript
type Person = { name ∷ String, age ∷ Int }

JA.indexedArray "Test Object" $
  { name: _, age: _ }
    <$> _.name ~ index 0 JA.string
    <*> _.age ~ index 1 JA.int
```
declarations.title: indexedArray

declarations.comments: A codec for an item in an `indexedArray`.
declarations.title: index

declarations.comments: Codec type for `JObject` prop/value pairs.
declarations.title: JPropCodec

declarations.comments: A codec for objects that are encoded with specific properties.
declarations.title: object

declarations.comments: A codec for a property of an object.
declarations.title: prop

declarations.comments:
The starting value for a object-record codec. Used with `recordProp` it
provides a convenient method for defining codecs for record types that
encode into JSON objects of the same shape.

For example:
```
myRecordCodec =
  object "MyRecord" $ record
    # recordProp (SProxy :: SProxy "tag") tagCodec
    # recordProp (SProxy :: SProxy "value") valueCodec
```
declarations.title: record

declarations.comments:
Used with `record` to define codecs for record types that encode into JSON
objects of the same shape. See the comment on `record` for an example.
declarations.title: recordProp

declarations.comments: Helper function for defining recursive codecs.
declarations.title: fix

declarations.comments:
Adapts an existing codec with a pair of functions to allow a value to be
further refined. If the inner decoder fails an `UnexpectedValue` error will
be raised for JSON input.

This function is named as such as the pair of functions it accepts
correspond with the `preview` and `view` functions of a `Prism`-style lens.

For example, in order to parse a mapping from an enum to strings, which
doesn't match up nicely with `Data.Codec.Argonaut.Sum.enumSum` we can use
prismaticCodec:

```purescript
data Direction = North | South | West | East

directionCodec :: JsonCodec Direction
directionCodec = prismaticCodec dec enc string
  where
    dec = case _ of
      "N" -> Just North
      "S" -> Just South
      "W" -> Just West
      "E" -> Just East
      _ -> Nothing

    enc = case _ of
      North -> "N"
      South -> "S"
      West -> "W"
      East -> "E"
```
declarations.title: prismaticCodec

declarations.comments:
`GCodec` is defined as a `Profunctor` so that `lmap` can be used to target
specific fields when defining a codec for a product type. This operator
is a convenience for that:

``` purescript
tupleCodec =
  Tuple
    <$> fst ~ fstCodec
    <*> snd ~ sndCodec
```

A codec for `Tuple` values.

Encodes as a two-element array in JSON.
declarations.title: tuple

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Map` values.

Encodes as an array of two-element key/value arrays in JSON.
declarations.title: map

declarations.comments:
A codec for `List` values.

Encodes as an array in JSON.
declarations.title: list

declarations.comments: A codec for `Either` values.
declarations.title: either

declarations.comments:
A codec for `Maybe` values.

Encodes and decodes `Nothing` as `null`

Note: this codec cannot represent nested `Maybe` values in a lossless
manner.
declarations.title: maybe

declarations.comments:
A codec for `StrMap` values.

Encodes as a JSON object with the keys as properties.

```purescript
encode (strMap int) (Data.StrMap.fromFoldable [Tuple "a" 1, Tuple "b" 2]) == "{ \"a\": 1, \"b\": 2}"
```
declarations.title: strMap

declarations.comments:
Encodes nullary sums with a Generic instance as strings that match the constructor names.

```purescript
import Data.Argonaut as J

data MySum = Ctor1 | Ctor2 | MoarCtors
derive instance genericMySum ∷ Generic MySum _

encode nullarySum Ctor1 == J.fromString "Ctor1"
decode nullarySum (J.fromString "MoarCtors") == Right MoarCtors
```
declarations.title: nullarySum

declarations.comments:
When dealing with a JSON object that may be missing a field, this codec
can be used to alter the JSON before parsing to ensure a default value is
present instead.
declarations.title: addDefaultField

declarations.comments: Re-maps the value of a field in a JSON object.
declarations.title: updateField

declarations.comments:
When dealing with a JSON object that may be missing a field, this codec
can be used to alter the JSON before parsing to ensure a default value is
present instead. Similar to `addDefaultField`, but allows existing values
to be modified also.
declarations.title: addDefaultOrUpdateField

declarations.comments:
When dealing with a JSON object that has had a field name changed, this
codec can be used to alter the JSON before parsing to ensure the new field
name is used instead
declarations.title: renameField

declarations.comments:
Prepares an object from a legacy codec for use in a `Variant` or
`taggedSum` codec.

For an input like:
```{ "tag": "tag", "x": 1, "y": 2, "z": 3 }```
the result will be:
```{ "tag": "tag", "value": { "x": 1, "y": 2, "z": 3 } }```

For an input like:
```{ "tag": "tag", "value": 1, "foo": 2 }```
the result will be:
```{ "tag": "tag", "value": { "value": 1, "foo": 2 }```

If the value is already in the expected form, where there is only `value`
and no other keys (aside from `tag`):
```{ "tag": "tag", "value": true }```
the result will be the same as the input.

If the tag field is missing from the input, it will also be missing in the
output.
declarations.title: nestForTagged

declarations.comments:
Constructs a record codec from a record of codecs.

```purescript
type Person = { name ∷ String, age ∷ Int }

personCodec ∷ CA.JsonCodec Person
personCodec = CA.object "Person" (record { name: CA.string, age: CA.int })

decode personCodec "{ name: \"Carl\", age:\"25\" }" == Right { name: "Carl", age: 25 }
```
declarations.title: record

declarations.comments:
A helper for defining JSON codecs for "enum" sum types, where every
constructor is nullary, and the type will be encoded as a string.
declarations.title: enumSum

declarations.comments:
A helper for defining JSON codecs for sum types. To ensure exhaustivity
there needs to be a mapping to and from a tag type for the type to be
encoded.

- The first argument is the name of the type being decoded, for error
  message purposes.
- The second argument maps a tag value to a string to use in the encoding.
- The second argument maps a string back to a tag value during decoding.
- The third argument returns either a constant value or a decoder function
  based on a tag value.
- The fourth argument returns a tag value and optional encoded value to
  store for a constructor of the sum.
declarations.title: taggedSum

declarations.comments:
Allows building codecs for variants in combination with variantCase.

Commonly used to write decoders for sum-types, by providing a mapping from
and to a Variant from that type and then using `dimap`.

```purescript
codecMaybe ∷ ∀ a. JA.JsonCodec a → JA.JsonCodec (Maybe a)
codecMaybe codecA =
  dimap toVariant fromVariant
    (JAV.variant
      # JAV.variantCase _Just (Right codecA)
      # JAV.variantCase _Nothing (Left unit))
  where
  toVariant = case _ of
    Just a → V.inj _Just a
    Nothing → V.inj _Nothing unit
  fromVariant = V.case_
    # V.on _Just Just
    # V.on _Nothing (const Nothing)
  _Just = SProxy ∷ SProxy "just"
  _Nothing = SProxy ∷ SProxy "nothing"
```
declarations.title: variant
